game_commentary:
So, I try something else, as now my Queen is mobilized, and more importantly are my Rooks being connected, at once.
,Trying to exchange pawns, but I missed the big picture.
,? Not knowing what else to do, I centralize my other Rook.  But, exchanging was needed here.  The big picture is what's coming.  At worst, I thought that this just lost tempo which as you know, isn't my big concern.  That would be me trying to dig out my collection of chess quotes, rather then seeing the entire board.  But, I overlooked it here as it doesn't just gain tempo.  What I forgot is that my Nf6 is still pinned, so I can't get out.  At best, Stanley is going to get a favorable exchange.
,?? Figuring that there's no way out, my attitude is very similar to my second game with Ken.  As I got too comfortable here.  My attitude is that if Stanley takes my N, I'll recapture his B.  But, I overlook what comes next since my Queen will be attacked.  And, that's why it's a free piece.  Had I been a little more cautious, I would've realized that 16...Nh7 was possible.  As that way, Stanley would win the exchange, as my N is more powerful.  But, it's better then losing material.
,As that's when Stanley retreats, and he told me that even if I prevented the immediate loss which we'll see in a little bit, he'd keep his advantage.  In other words, just like with Ken, Stanley wasn't going to give me the opportunity to win anything back. 
,Trying to figure out wherelse to go, I attempt to double up my Rooks.
,But, Stanley prevents that by attacking my Queen.
,After which, Stanley played this.  I'm not sure why, but I start attacking.
,I figured out that he was worried about mate.  Personally, I don't think any of his last two moves were mated since I didn't see any way to mate him.
,So, I go back to my plan of doubling up.
,And, Stanley intends to exchange.
,?? But, I refuse by trying to use my King as a weapon since we're nearing the endgame.  That's because I don't want to liquidate since I'm behind.  Stanley, however, pointed out that this is the move that loses at once.  As I overlooked how powerful that N is.  Instead, the best move was to exchange with 22...Bxg4, as we'll see later on.  
,Not seeing the point and figuring that Stanley might be trying to mate me, I attack his N with my next move.
,But, this was played instead.
,I can't take with the King but thought that I was fine with his move, however...
,Once Stanley played this, I resigned.  That's because my Queen is trapped with this pin.  Therefore, at the very least, he will win the Queen for a piece, at which, there is no point in continuing.  After this game, a discussion with Jack, Stanley, and I ensues.  Jack: Why didn't you exchange with 22...Bxg4  Joe: I didn't want to exchange because that would liquidate further since I'm behind.  The idea is not exchanging pieces when behind.  Stanley: True, but there is a danger that you overlooked which is my N.  Jack: How many times must I tell you to be aware of the N?  Those Knights are very dangerous, and therefore, should not let them come in like this.  Stanley: Had you exchanged, I would've remained with the advantage, but black would've been ok.  By refusing it was game over for black.

This was a good game.  A lot of moves made to allow for me to disguise my next move and then a capture may be on the cards. -
,White went with f4 Bird's Opening and black chose d5.
,White continued to move on the kingside with h3.
,Black now decided to lock white's f4 pawn in place with f5.
,White's next move was Nf6 staking claims to squares e5 and g5.
,Black went with Nc6.
,White pushed pawn to e3 protecting his pawn at f4.
,Black also protected his centre pawns with e6.
,Now white pins the knight at c3 with Bb5.
,Black brings his bishop to d7 ready to capture white's LB if it captures the knight.
,White develops his knight to c3.
,White pushes a pawn to a6 and is attacking white's LB.
,White captures the knight at c3.
,Black recaptures the LB with his LB.
,White now attacks the LB with Ne5 whilst protected by the pawn at f4.  This is a great square in the centre of the board and is attacking f7.
,Black retreats his LB back to d7 and the knight on e5 is still able to capture but would be recaptured so decides to sit in wait.  White decides to castle instead.  
,Black brings his DB to c5 and is looking at the diagonal to the king on g1.  There is a pawn on the diagonal and not much else.
,White decides to attack the DB with pawn to d4.
,So black retreats his DB back to e7.
,White decides to move pawn to a4 taking control of the b5 square whilst protected by the knight at c3 and the rook at a1.
